video.title: Ori and the Will of the Wisps (Zero Punctuation)

captions.text:
The usual indie arty platformer theme of small
innocent child in big scary world is like

the missionary position. There&#39;s nothing inherently
wrong with it, some interesting things have

been done with it, but when it&#39;s all you fucking
do you&#39;ll swiftly be desperately hankering

to break the monotony with just one suck job
or nipple clamp. The thing about small child

scary world though is that it rarely does
sequels, because the underlying theme of small

child scary world is coming of age and/or
loss of innocence, and you can&#39;t lose your

innocence twice. Well, I suppose you could
lose it in stages. Say, lose half when you

find out that Santa isn&#39;t real, lose the other
half the first time you take it up the arse.

And speaking of comfort zones, we come to
Ori and the Will of the Wisps, sequel to small

glowing child cat rabbit thing in scary world
Metroidvania title Ori and the Blind Forest,

and the direction it&#39;s apparently chosen to
go in for this sequel is a U-turn. See, it

doesn&#39;t take long into Ori and the Walkers
of the Crisps to realise that the story is

hitting the exact same beats as the last game,
except to the montage of deliriously peaceful

family life at the start before everything
goes to shit they&#39;ve added a baby owl with

a nice fresh virginal innocence to ruin instead
of Ori&#39;s this time. Missionary position again,

is it, darling? Okay, I&#39;ll get the sheet with
a hole in and the picture of Jesus.

You might reasonably think from looking at
the promotional art - I almost said box art,

there, but come on, like anyone buys games
in boxes, from shops, like a twat, and incidentally

I think the world owes me and every other
gamer a debt of gratitude for being way ahead

on the whole self-isolation thing - that the
owl is some kind of sidekick or co-op partner,

but that&#39;s the case for all of half a level
and the rest of the time it&#39;s Ori on their

own again and the owl is mere feathered Maguffin.
Magriffin, perhaps. Again Ori finds themselves

lost in a scary Metroidvania world full of
hostile balls of glowing snot - not the same

scary Metroidvania world, a new if hauntingly
similar one that was next door to the first

one the whole time, and again the big villain
is a giant scary owl. Not the same giant scary

owl - a new, slightly scarier owl that the
other giant scary owls didn&#39;t want anything

to do with. So I guess this is how we&#39;re ramping
up the stakes for the sequel. New, never-before-seen

depths of owl antisocialness. No but seriously
now.

In the fullness of time I felt bad about my
very huffy review of the first Ori and the

Last Crusade. I mean, you could hardly call
the games lazy. They&#39;re beautifully drawn

and animated with a lovely soundtrack, the
core gameplay is smooth and satisfying, and

the emotional moments hit the right emotion.
I couldn&#39;t remember what had rubbed me up

the wrong way about it. So I eagerly started
Ori and the Way of the Wank and shortly afterwards

said &quot;Oh I remember now.&quot; It&#39;s not that it&#39;s
bad. It&#39;s very stylish, I just don&#39;t think

there&#39;s much substance to it. Once again the
nebulous negative force we&#39;re up against is

&quot;the darkness&quot;, which has no agenda beyond
making all the nice people sad and the local

boss monsters bastards, requiring that we
help out through therapeutic beating the glowing

snot out of them. Look, I know this isn&#39;t
Tinker Tailor Soldier Cat Rabbit Thing and

I shouldn&#39;t expect complex plotting from my
fantasy animal platformers, but the mythic

tone and sweeping soundtrack makes me think
that it thinks its story is epic and profound,

when it&#39;s actually kinda shallow. Drive out
the darkness and restore the light? Ooh, good

idea, maybe I wouldn&#39;t bump into things so
much.

The game&#39;s backed by Microsoft and there&#39;s
a vibe of corporate committee thinking around

it. It reminds me of how Hollywood pumps its
most crassly gigantic budgets into movies

with no more profound message than &quot;it&#39;s bad
to murder everyone with explosions&quot; because

any more controversial statement would offend
the Chinese government. The first game had

one original thought in the form of having
you manually plonk down your save points,

which was slightly wobbly in execution so
naturally it&#39;s been kicked to the curb in

favour of making a game that&#39;s more like Hollow
Knight. Because Hollow Knight was popular

and did well and has therefore gained the
favour of the giant money machine, all praise

its benevolent wisdom. So it&#39;s got a similar
badge system and a similar emphasis on NPCs,

it&#39;s even got the one mapmaker dude you keep
running into in the world who sells you a

map for the current area. Except in Hollow
Knight you flat out wouldn&#39;t have a map until

you did that as a deliberate design choice
to make the player really think about their

new environment without handholding for a
while, and Ori and the Will of the Smiths

automaps for you regardless. Maybe orienteering
offends the Chinese government too.

And of course there&#39;s the spectacular boss
fights, all three and a half of them. One

of which is a giant spider, and giant spider
bosses in Metroidvania games are like turret

sections in shooters in that they&#39;re officially
the point where the designers ran out of ideas,

but let&#39;s not be too churlish because the
boss fights where there&#39;s actually a boss

and you&#39;re actually fighting it are a rare
treat when half the time the game will have

a cinematic chase sequence instead, which
are about as much fun as working a seed out

of your teeth while listening to the Uncharted
soundtrack. Inevitably these involve having

to perfectly carry out a strict sequence of
movements and starting all over again at the

slightest pause or mistake. Where all the
impact is lost after the first two or three

restarts and it&#39;s only cinematic if you&#39;re
in a cinema where the projectionist has advanced

Parkinson&#39;s disease. As I&#39;ve said before,
such things aren&#39;t precisely the same as press

X to not die QTE sequences but they certainly
share a bathroom and use the same electric

pube trimmer. Oh hark at Mr Grumpy Pants reaching
for things to complain about because it&#39;s

easier than changing into a pair of trousers
that&#39;s more positive spirited.

Alright, it&#39;s still a beautiful game and when
it isn&#39;t pausing to very cinematically wank

the budget off on screen the core platforming
gameplay is fun and skillful, although I hate

how we only have three ability slots mapped
to three of the face buttons, &#39;cos one of

those abilities is your standard attack, which
you will never unequip, and at least one of

them needs to be whatever traversal power
gets you through the current area so really

you&#39;ve only one free slot, and I&#39;ve got all
this money and the merchant&#39;s children are

starving and eating each others&#39; toenail clippings
to survive but I don&#39;t want to fucking buy

any of the merchant&#39;s fancy combat abilities
because I only have one slot and I don&#39;t want

to have to keep pausing the game to remap
my controls mid-combat like I&#39;m trying to

drive a car with a starving Tamagotchi on
the passenger seat because someone&#39;s never

heard of button combinations - oh dear Grumpy
Pants is back from the dry cleaners. Sorry,

I&#39;m still not sure why the Ori games affect
me this way, I see a perfectly playable game

about a cute little animal thing and I instantly
get suspicious. It&#39;s probably lingering trauma
from looking at Sonic the Hedgehog fanart.
